messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) is a United States federal law that defines and protects the institution of marriage. enacted in 1996. It was introduced by Georgia Representative Bob Barr and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma. The Act was intended by Congress to reflect and honor a collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality. It also defined marriage for federal purposes as the legal union of a man and a woman as husband and wife, and a spouse as a husband or wife of the opposite sex. Section 3 of DOMA defines marriage and spouse for federal purposes. Section 3 codified non-recognition of same - sex marriages for all federal purposes, including insurance benefits for government employees, social security survivors ' benefits, immigration, bankruptcy, and the filing of joint tax returns, as well as excluding same - sex spouses from the scope of laws protecting families of federal officers, laws evaluating financial aid eligibility, and federal ethics laws applicable to opposite - sex spouses.

contexts.text:
Defense of Marriage Act
Georgia Representative Bob Barr , then a Republican , authored the Defense of Marriage Act and introduced it in the House of Representatives on May 7 , 1996 . Senator Don Nickles , ( R ) Oklahoma , introduced the bill in the Senate . The House Judiciary Committee stated that the Act was intended by Congress to `` reflect and honor a collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality '' . The Act 's congressional sponsors stated , `` ( T ) he bill amends the U.S. Code to make explicit what has been understood under federal law for over 200 years ; that a marriage is the legal union of a man and a woman as husband and wife , and a spouse is a husband or wife of the opposite sex . ''

contexts.text:
Defense of Marriage Act
The bill moved through Congress on a legislative fast track and met with overwhelming approval in both houses of the Republican - controlled Congress . On July 12 , 1996 , with only 65 Democrats and then Rep. Bernie Sanders ( Independent - Vermont ) and Rep. Steve Gunderson ( Republican - Wisconsin ) , in opposition , 342 members of the U.S. House of Representatives -- 224 Republicans and 118 Democrats -- voted to pass DOMA . Then , on September 10 , 1996 , 84 Senators -- a majority of the Democratic Senators and all of the Republicans -- voted in favor of DOMA . Democratic Senators voted for the bill 32 to 14 ( with Pryor of Arkansas absent ) , and Democratic Representatives voted for it 118 to 65 , with 15 not participating . All Republicans in both houses voted for the bill with the sole exception of the one openly gay Republican Congressman , Rep. Steve Gunderson of Wisconsin .

contexts.text:
Defense of Marriage Act
The Defense of Marriage Act ( DOMA ) ( Pub. L. 104 -- 199 , 110 Stat. 2419 , enacted September 21 , 1996 , 1 U.S.C. § 7 and 28 U.S.C. § 1738C ) was a United States federal law that , prior to being ruled unconstitutional , defined marriage for federal purposes as the union of one man and one woman , and allowed states to refuse to recognize same - sex marriages granted under the laws of other states . Until Section 3 of the Act was struck down in 2013 ( United States v. Windsor ) , DOMA , in conjunction with other statutes , had barred same - sex married couples from being recognized as `` spouses '' for purposes of federal laws , effectively barring them from receiving federal marriage benefits . DOMA 's passage did not prevent individual states from recognizing same - sex marriage , but it imposed constraints on the benefits received by all legally married same - sex couples .

messages.original_text: The Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) is a United States federal law enacted in 1996. It was introduced by Georgia Representative Bob Barr and Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma. The Act was intended by Congress to reflect and honor a collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality. It defined marriage for federal purposes as the legal union of a man and a woman as husband and wife, and a spouse as a husband or wife of the opposite sex. The bill moved quickly through Congress and was passed by an overwhelming majority in both houses of the Republican-controlled Congress. On July 12, 1996, 342 members of the U.S. House of Representatives voted to pass DOMA, and on September 10, 1996, 84 Senators voted in favor of DOMA. The Act was signed into law by President Bill Clinton on September 21, 1996. However, Section 3 of DOMA, which defined marriage and spouse for federal purposes, was struck down by the Supreme Court on June 26, 2013, in the case of United States v. Windsor.

contexts.text:
Defense of Marriage Act
Section 1 . Short title This Act may be cited as the `` Defense of Marriage Act '' . Section 2 . Powers reserved to the states No State , territory , or possession of the United States , or Indian tribe , shall be required to give effect to any public act , record , or judicial proceeding of any other State , territory , possession , or tribe respecting a relationship between persons of the same sex that is treated as a marriage under the laws of such other State , territory , possession , or tribe , or a right or claim arising from such relationship . Section 3 . Definition of marriage In determining the meaning of any Act of Congress , or of any ruling , regulation , or interpretation of the various administrative bureaus and agencies of the United States , the word ' marriage ' means only a legal union between one man and one woman as husband and wife , and the word ' spouse ' refers only to a person of the opposite sex who is a husband or a wife .
contexts.title: Defense of Marriage Act

This definition was used to deny federal recognition to same-sex marriages, which meant that same-sex married couples were not eligible for federal marriage benefits. As of now, marriage is legally recognized as a union between two consenting adults, regardless of their sex or gender identity, in many jurisdictions around the world.

messages.text: The typical wedding involves a couple proclaiming their commitment to one another in front of their close relatives and friends , often presided over by a religious figure such as a minister , priest , or rabbi , depending upon the faith of the couple . In traditional Christian ceremonies , the bride 's father will `` give away '' ( hand off ) the bride to the groom . Secular weddings are also common , often presided over by a judge , Justice of the Peace , or other municipal official . At a wedding reception , the father of the bride , in his role as host , regularly offers the first toast , thanking the guests for attending , offering tasteful remembrances of the bride 's childhood , and wishing the newlyweds a happy life together . The best man usually proposes a toast in the form of best wishes and congratulations to the newlyweds . A best man 's toast takes the form of a short speech ( 3 -- 5 minutes ) that combines a mixture of humor and sincerity . The actual `` toast '' is then delivered at the end of the speech and is a short phrase wishing the newlyweds a happy , healthy , loving life together . The maid of honor may follow suit , appropriately tailoring her comments to the bride . The groom may offer the final toast , thanking the bride 's parents for hosting the wedding , the wedding party for their participation , and finally dedicating the toast to the bridesmaids .

contexts.text:
Toast (honor)
Toasts are generally offered at times of celebration or commemoration , including certain holidays , such as New Year 's Eve . Other occasions include retirement celebrations , housewarming parties , births , etc . The protocol for toasting at weddings is comparatively elaborate and fixed . At a wedding reception , the father of the bride , in his role as host , regularly offers the first toast , thanking the guests for attending , offering tasteful remembrances of the bride 's childhood , and wishing the newlyweds a happy life together . The best man usually proposes a toast in the form of best wishes and congratulations to the newlyweds . A best man 's toast takes the form of a short speech ( 3 -- 5 minutes ) that combines a mixture of humor and sincerity . The humor often comes in the shape of the best man telling jokes at the groom 's expense whilst the sincerity incorporates the praise and complimentary comments that a best man should make about the bride and groom , amongst others . The actual `` toast '' is then delivered at the end of the speech and is a short phrase wishing the newlyweds a happy , healthy , loving life together . The maid of honor may follow suit , appropriately tailoring her comments to the bride . The groom may offer the final toast , thanking the bride 's parents for hosting the wedding , the wedding party for their participation , and finally dedicating the toast to the bridesmaids .
contexts.title: Toast (honor)

messages.original_text: The way weddings are celebrated can vary greatly depending on cultural, religious, and personal preferences. Generally, a wedding is a ceremony where two people are united in marriage. It often involves an exchange of vows and the exchange of symbolic items such as rings. Weddings can be civil or religious and can take place in a variety of locations, from a courthouse or a church to a beach or a garden. They can be small, intimate affairs with only close family and friends in attendance, or they can be large, elaborate events with hundreds of guests. There are also many traditions and customs associated with weddings, such as the bride wearing a white dress, the groom wearing a tuxedo, and the throwing of the bouquet. However, these traditions can also vary and are often adapted to suit the couple's personal style and beliefs. Ultimately, the most important aspect of a wedding is the commitment being made between the two people getting married.

messages.text: What is the meaning of the glass being broken at a Jewish wedding?

messages.speaker: agent
messages.text: The primary reason is that joy must always be tempered . This is based on two accounts in the Talmud of rabbis who , upon seeing that their son 's wedding celebration was getting out of hand , broke a vessel -- in the second case a glass -- to calm things down . Another explanation is that it is a reminder that despite the joy , Jews still mourn the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem .

Defense of Marriage Act
The Defense of Marriage Act ( DOMA ) ( Pub. L. 104 -- 199 , 110 Stat. 2419 , enacted September 21 , 1996 , 1 U.S.C. § 7 and 28 U.S.C. § 1738C ) was a United States federal law that , prior to being ruled unconstitutional , defined marriage for federal purposes as the union of one man and one woman , and allowed states to refuse to recognize same - sex marriages granted under the laws of other states . Until Section 3 of the Act was struck down in 2013 ( United States v. Windsor ) , DOMA , in conjunction with other statutes , had barred same - sex married couples from being recognized as `` spouses '' for purposes of federal laws , effectively barring them from receiving federal marriage benefits . DOMA 's passage did not prevent individual states from recognizing same - sex marriage , but it imposed constraints on the benefits received by all legally married same - sex couples .

contexts.text:
Jewish wedding
The origin of this custom is unknown , although many reasons have been given . The primary reason is that joy must always be tempered . This is based on two accounts in the Talmud of rabbis who , upon seeing that their son 's wedding celebration was getting out of hand , broke a vessel -- in the second case a glass -- to calm things down . Another explanation is that it is a reminder that despite the joy , Jews still mourn the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem . Because of this , some recite the verses `` If I forget thee / O Jerusalem ... '' ( Ps. 137 : 5 ) at this point . Many other reasons have been given by traditional authorities .
contexts.title: Jewish wedding

ml.tokens.model_text: What is the meaning of the glass being broken at a Jewish wedding?

messages.original_text: At a Jewish wedding, the breaking of a glass is a significant custom that takes place at the end of the ceremony. It is typically performed by the groom, although some couples choose to do it together. The breaking of the glass has several meanings and interpretations. One common explanation is that it serves as a reminder of the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem. It is also seen as a symbol of the fragility of human relationships and the need to protect and cherish them. Another interpretation is that the glass represents the couple's past, and by breaking it, they are symbolically leaving it behind and starting their new life together. Regardless of the exact meaning, the breaking of the glass is a powerful and emotional moment that adds depth and significance to the wedding ceremony. After the glass is broken, the guests typically shout "Mazel Tov!" which means "good luck" or "congratulations" in Hebrew.

contexts.text:
Defense of Marriage Act
The Defense of Marriage Act ( DOMA ) ( Pub. L. 104 -- 199 , 110 Stat. 2419 , enacted September 21 , 1996 , 1 U.S.C. § 7 and 28 U.S.C. § 1738C ) was a United States federal law that , prior to being ruled unconstitutional , defined marriage for federal purposes as the union of one man and one woman , and allowed states to refuse to recognize same - sex marriages granted under the laws of other states . Until Section 3 of the Act was struck down in 2013 ( United States v. Windsor ) , DOMA , in conjunction with other statutes , had barred same - sex married couples from being recognized as `` spouses '' for purposes of federal laws , effectively barring them from receiving federal marriage benefits . DOMA 's passage did not prevent individual states from recognizing same - sex marriage , but it imposed constraints on the benefits received by all legally married same - sex couples .

messages.original_text:
Prior to the Supreme Court's ruling in the United States v. Windsor case in 2013, the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) prevented same-sex married couples from being recognized as "spouses" for purposes of federal laws, which effectively barred them from receiving federal marriage benefits, including immigration benefits. However, after the Supreme Court's decision in 2013, same-sex married couples became eligible for the same immigration benefits as different-sex married couples.
Under U.S. immigration law, a U.S. citizen or permanent resident can sponsor their spouse for a green card, allowing them to live and work in the United States permanently. This process is known as "family-based immigration." With the repeal of DOMA, same-sex married couples are now able to take advantage of this process, just like different-sex married couples.
It's worth noting that the immigration process for same-sex couples can still be complex, particularly if the couple lives in a state or country that does not recognize same-sex marriage. However, with the help of an experienced immigration attorney, same-sex couples can navigate the process and secure the immigration benefits they are entitled to.

Defense of Marriage Act
Initially introduced in May 1996 , DOMA passed both houses of Congress by large , veto - proof majorities and was signed into law by President Bill Clinton in September 1996 . contexts.text:
Defense of Marriage Act
The Defense of Marriage Act ( DOMA ) ( Pub. L. 104 -- 199 , 110 Stat. 2419 , enacted September 21 , 1996 , 1 U.S.C. § 7 and 28 U.S.C. § 1738C ) was a United States federal law that , prior to being ruled unconstitutional , defined marriage for federal purposes as the union of one man and one woman , and allowed states to refuse to recognize same - sex marriages granted under the laws of other states . Until Section 3 of the Act was struck down in 2013 ( United States v. Windsor ) , DOMA , in conjunction with other statutes , had barred same - sex married couples from being recognized as `` spouses '' for purposes of federal laws , effectively barring them from receiving federal marriage benefits . DOMA 's passage did not prevent individual states from recognizing same - sex marriage , but it imposed constraints on the benefits received by all legally married same - sex couples .

contexts.text:
History of immigration to the United States
Restriction proceeded piecemeal over the course of the late 19th and early 20th centuries , but immediately after the end of World War I ( 1914 -- 18 ) and into the early 1920s , Congress changed the nation 's basic policy about immigration . The National Origins Formula of 1921 ( and its final form in 1924 ) not only restricted the number of immigrants who might enter the United States , but also assigned slots according to quotas based on national origins . A complicated piece of legislation , it essentially gave preference to immigrants from Central , Northern and Western Europe , severely limiting the numbers from Russia and Southern Europe , and declared all potential immigrants from Asia unworthy of entry into the United States .
contexts.title: History of immigration to the United States

There can be various restrictions to immigration in the United States, some of which may affect same-sex couples. These restrictions can include:
1. Eligibility requirements: To be eligible for immigration benefits, individuals must meet certain requirements, such as passing medical exams, background checks, and providing necessary documentation.
2. Inadmissibility grounds: Certain individuals may be inadmissible to the United States due to factors such as criminal history, security risks, or health issues.
3. Numerical limitations: There are limits to the number of visas that can be issued each year in certain categories, which can result in wait times for some applicants.
4. DOMA restrictions (prior to 2013): Before the Supreme Court's ruling in the United States v. Windsor case in 2013, the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) prevented same-sex married couples from being recognized as "spouses" for purposes of federal laws, which effectively barred them from receiving federal marriage benefits, including immigration benefits.
However, after the Supreme Court's decision in 2013, same-sex married couples became eligible for the same immigration benefits as different-sex married couples. It's worth noting that the immigration process for same-sex couples can still be complex, particularly if the couple lives in a state or country that does not recognize same-sex marriage. However, with the help of an experienced immigration attorney, same-sex couples can navigate the process and secure the immigration benefits they are entitled to.
